block.p: LEAD: THE ECONOMY Construction of new homes slid last month to the lowest level in more than six years, the Government reported. The real estate industry said in a separate report that prices of existing homes were rising with much less force nationwide. [ Page A1. ] The Senate and House might have to relinquish some control over top military programs if the U.S.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Construction of new homes slid last month to the lowest level in more than six years, the Government reported. The real estate industry said in a separate report that prices of existing homes were rising with much less force nationwide. [ Page A1. ] The Senate and House might have to relinquish some control over top military programs if the U.S.

THE ECONOMY Construction of new homes slid last month to the lowest level in more than six years, the Government reported. The real estate industry said in a separate report that prices of existing homes were rising with much less force nationwide. [ Page A1. ] The Senate and House might have to relinquish some control over top military programs if the U.S. is to maintain the superiority of its military technology, a Congressional study said. [ D7. ] The Air Force suspended payment on Loral's contract to build a radar warning system for the F-16 fighter. [ D7. ] INTERNATIONAL The Senate defeated an attempt to block the Administration's agreement to build an advanced fighter plane with Japan. The 52-to-47 vote reflected lawmakers' anger over the $7 billion deal. [ D1. ] Robert Maxwell and Rupert Murdoch joined forces in a multimillion-dollar deal linking satellite and cable television. [ D1. ] Commerce Secretary Mosbacher called on Moscow to stop stealing high-technology secrets. [ D9. ] Talks resume today between Mexico and its commercial bank lenders on a debt reduction and restructuring package. [ D16. ] COMPANIES Minorco conceded defeat in its $4.2 billion bid for Consolidated Gold Fields. British law bars another bid for a year. [ D1. ] Home Box Office will enter the basic cable business with a 24-hour all-comedy channel. [ D1. ] Continental canceled its increase in discount fares, saying competitors had not matched its move. [ D5. ] . Procter & Gamble has put Crush International up for sale, the latest giant to fail in the soft-drink business. [ D2. ] Cray Research's stock plunged $6, or 10.8 percent, to $49.75, after the news that its founder would start a new company. [ D5. ] A Federal bankruptcy judge said Eastern Airlines' management was acting properly in seeking to sell the shuttle. [ D5. ] I.B.M. introduced, as expected, an ambitious set of software that addresses the changing role of the mainframe. [ D4. ] Southmark lost more than $1 billion in the first quarter. It said the loss reflected problem real estate loans. [ D4. ] MARKETS The S.E.C. charged a former paralegal with Skadden, Arps with violating securities laws by passing on insider information. [ D9. ] Stock prices fell after rising for four sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.44 points, to 2,453.45. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading, as longer issues outperformed short-term notes and bills. [ D16. ] Yields were flat for C.D.'s and bank money market accounts. [ D24. ] The dollar's rally stalled amid traders' nervousness over forthcoming Government data. [ D17. ] Grain and soybean futures prices plunged after forecasts of increased rain. [ D17. ] TECHNOLOGY Experimental vehicles that burn methanol are turning up with increasing frequency. [ D8. ] Someday, shoppers will dig through the onion bin reading labels on each onion that indicate its sweetness and pungency. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Can America curb its addiction to fossil fuels? Fears focus on demand. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Bergner's acquisition of Carson Pirie Scott shows how appealing regional retailers have become. Market Place. [ D10. ] David Ogilvy said he was ''miserable'' after Ogilvy agreed to be taken over by WPP. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ]
